Graphical abstract This review highlights the categories of copper-based catalysts, optimization strategies and reaction mechanisms for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to alcohols (methanol, ethanol, and propanol). Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) technology, which enables carbon capture storage and resource utilization by reducing CO2 to valuable chemicals or fuels, has become a global research hotspot in recent decades. Among the many products of CO2RR (carbon monoxide, acids, aldehydes and alcohols, olefins, etc.), alcohols (methanol, ethanol, propanol, etc.) have a higher market value and energy density, but it is also more difficult to produce. Copper is known to be effective in catalyzing CO2 to high value-added alcohols, but with poor selectivity. The progress of Cu-based catalysts for the selective generation of alcohols, including copper oxides, bimetals, single atoms and composites is reviewed. Meanwhile, to improve Cu-based catalyst activity and modulate product selectivity, the modulation strategies are straighten out, including morphological regulation, crystalline surface, oxidation state, as well as elemental doping and defect engineering. Based on the research progress of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction for alcohol production on Cu-based materials, the reaction pathways and the key intermediates of the electrocatalytic CO2RR to methanol, ethanol and propanol are summarized. Finally, the problems of traditional electrocatalytic CO2RR are introduced, and the future applications of machine learning and theoretical calculations are prospected. An in-depth discussion and a comprehensive review of the reaction mechanism, catalyst types and regulation strategies were carried out with a view to promoting the development of electrocatalytic CO2RR to alcohols. Keywords Electrocatalytic CO2RR Cu-based catalyst Alcohols Reaction mechanism Regulation strategies 1 Introduction Nowadays, the world's energy production and chemical industries continue to dependent on fossil fuels (coal, oil and natural gas, etc.). However, fossil fuels combustion releases vast quantities of CO2 into the atmosphere, which is considered as a major driver of climate change [1]. CO2 capture, utilization and storage (CCUS), which aims to capture, purify store and recover CO2 in order to in order to equalize the climate-negative impacts of CO2, is considered an important component of climate change mitigation and contributes to a low-carbon and sustainable future [2]. During the process, the efficient use of renewable energy sources for the conversion of CO2 into chemicals or fuels is significantly important. The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) technology, which transforms CO2 into valuable chemicals or fuels driven by renewable energy sources, is a highly prospective option to address the greenhouse effect and fossil fuel depletion [3,4]. Under the action of applied voltage and electrocatalysts, CO2 may be reduced to carbon monoxide, acids, alkanes, aldehydes and alcohols, etc. [5–8]. In recent decades, electrocatalytic CO2RR technologies have focused on the generation of one-carbon (C1) products such as CO, HCOOH and CH4, in which some efficient catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability have been discovered. Among these products, methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), and propanol (PrOH) have a greater potential for development due to their high market value, high energy density (Fig. 1 a), ease of storage and transmission, as well as direct use in fuel cells [9–12]. Among pure metal electrodes, copper electrodes are able to catalyze the conversion of CO2 to alcohols, but showed only limited selectivity and low activity in CO2RR, with the main products remaining carbon monoxide, formate and hydrocarbons [13–18]. With the emphasis on alcohol products, some electrocatalysts that can achieve higher selectivity in the generation of methanol [19–21], ethanol [22], and propanol [23] have also been discovered by scholars. Although much research has been conducted in the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR technology [6], there is a relative lack of research on the generation of more promising alcohols due to the C1 competing products (CO, HCOOH, CH4, etc.), the relationship between the activation and binding energies of the catalysts and intermediates, and the difficulty of coupling C–C bonds. Cu-based materials are the ideal catalysts for this difficult task, as Cu can simultaneously meet two basic requirements for CO2-to-alcohols: selective production of *CO instead of formate in the initial two-electron CO2RR stage, and a more moderate binding strength of *CO on the catalyst surface (Fig. 1b) [24]. Although alcohol products have high utilization value, the problem of low efficiency and selectivity of alcohol production is still the bottleneck that hinders the development of this technology. There have been reviews on Cu-based catalysts [26] and CO2 reduction to alcohols [27], etc., but there are few comprehensive summarized summaries of studies on electrocatalytic CO2-to-alcohols with Cu-based materials. Herein, based on the latest research, the possible conversion pathways of electrocatalytic CO2 to alcohols and the key intermediates in these pathways are sorted out. In addition, by summarizing the electrocatalysts used to generate methanol, ethanol and propanol, the modulation strategy of Cu-based catalysts were derived, providing a technical reference for the synthesis of catalysts for the selective generation of alcohols. Finally, the existing problems in the conversion of CO2-to-alcohols are analyzed and the outlook is presented. This study aims to present deep understanding of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to alcohols and to contribute to further optimization of research and technological breakthroughs. 2 Effects of electrocatalytic conditions 2.1 Potential The potential has a strong influence on the products and efficiency of CO2RR. Table 1 lists the onset potentials and half-reactions of CO2-to-alcohols and the precipitation of hydrogen by electrolysis of water [28]. It can be seen that the theoretical applied voltage required increases as the carbon number of the alcohol increases, indicating that the generation of C2+ alcohols (ethanol, propanol) is more difficult, which is due to its limitation by C–C coupling and multiple electron transfer. In addition, the actual potential required to drive CO2RR is much more negative than the theoretical potential due to the higher energy required for CO2 adsorption and activation to radical anions [29–31]. 2.2 Electrolyzer Electrolyzer design is also critical for CO2RR, which affects current density, Faraday efficiency, and stability [32]. H-cell have the advantage of simple assembly and are commonly used for rapid screening of highly efficient catalysts, but they are limited by issues such as low current densities and dissolved CO2 mass transfer. Liquid flow-cell have great potential in industry due to high current density, improved CO2 concentration and mass transfer efficiency [33]. Electrolyte cycling in liquid-phase flow-cell promotes diffusion (Fig. 2 a) and stabilizes the reaction environment, but there is a risk of gas diffusion electrodes being penetrated by the electrolyte [49]. This led to the emergence of membrane electrode assembly cell (MEA-cell). Unlike flow-cell, no cathodic electrolyte is required, and the catalyst is loaded on both sides of the membrane or on the gas diffusion layer (GDL), respectively, with a small CO2 diffusion distance (50 nm, [34]), thus solving the problem of low CO2 solubility and limited mass transfer (Fig. 2b). Sargent et al. achieved CO2RR current densities of more than 1 A cm−2, which initially reached the corresponding specifications required for industrialization [35]. Refs. [33,36] detailed the development and optimization strategies of flow-cell and MEA-cell. 2.3 Electrolyte Electrolytes play an important role in CO2RR by interacting with reactants and intermediates, altering CO2 solubility, pH, and stability of intermediates to affect molecular/ionic transport, and thus changing the microenvironment at the electrode interface. In electrolytes are mainly divided into three categories: aqueous solutions, organic solvents, and ionic liquids [6]. When dissolved in water, CO2 exists in three main inorganic forms: CO2 (aq), HCO3 −, and CO3 2− [38]. Changing the pH as well as the salinity of an aqueous solution can modulate the chemical equilibrium state of each form. It has been demonstrated that electrolyte composition (anions and cations) has a strong influence on electrocatalytic activity [39]. Agoritsa et al. found that the rate of CO2RR increases in the order of electrolyte cations: Na+ < Mg2+ < Ca2+ < Ba2+ < Al3+ < Zr4+ < Nd3+ < La3+ [40]. In addition, anions also have an effect on the polarization resistance, which is lower in the presence of OH− and HCO3 − than Cl−, suggesting that OH− or HCO3 − has a greater stabilizing effect on the electrode surface against CO2 − intermediate has a greater stabilizing effect [41]. The solubilization of CO2 is favored in organic solvents compared to aqueous electrolytes and increases with the presence of carbonyl groups in organic solvents, favoring higher mass transfer rates. In addition, a higher cathodic potential window is exhibited, allowing for the application of higher overpotentials and the reduction of CO2 to be obtained due to the inhibition of the simultaneous hydrogen precipitation reaction. However, effective CO2 reduction requires protons in the electrolyte, and due to the low availability of protons in organic solvents, the products typically formed by CO2 reduction are mainly CO and oxalate [42]. Room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) are ionically uncoordinated salts that are in the liquid phase at room temperature, e.g., [emim][BF4], [emim][ClO4], and [emim][NO3]. Ionic liquids tend to stabilize the intermediates formed during CO2 reduction by forming complexes, greatly reducing the overpotential for CO2 activation. In RTILs, anions play a key role in CO2 solubilization, whereas an increase in alkyl chain length in cations slightly increases CO2 solubility [43]. 3 Cu-based catalysts The typical studies of Cu-based catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 conversion to alcohols in recent years are shown in Table 2 , which mainly include Cu oxides, Cu-based bimetals, Cu monoatomic catalysts, Cu-carbon composites, etc. Most of them achieved better selectivity for alcohols generation compared with pure Cu. 3.1 Copper oxide catalysts 3.1.1 CO2-to-methanol It was proved that the proper oxidation of copper can improve the efficiency of methanol production to some extent [48,53]. A thin films of cuprous oxide was prepared by electro-deposition with yields of up to 43 μmol cm−2 h−1 and Faraday efficiency of CH3OH (FEMeOH) up to 38%, and it was concluded that Cu+ species could improve the stability of the intermediate and the selectivity for CH3OH by hydrogenating the oxygen atoms in the *OCH3 intermediate. In addition, they also found that the yield of CH3OH is dynamic and the copper oxide is simultaneously reduced to the metal Cu at the potential required for CO2RR [48]. In addition, a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) prepared by commercial deposition of Cu2O on carbon. The experiments mainly produced methanol as well as small amounts of ethanol and n-propanol with FE of alcohols (FEalcohols) of 54.8% (1.39 V vs. Ag/AgCl) [49]. 3.1.2 CO2-to-ethanol In addition, porous metal catalysts are of interest due to their higher specific surface area, improved electron mobility and mass transfer [73]. Multi-stage nanoporous Cu integrated with vanadium oxide (Cu@VO2) was used for electrocatalytic CO2RR. It showed that the multilevel nanoporous Cu skeleton not only facilitated the substance and electron transport, also provided a large surface area, thereby increasing the active site density. The vanadium oxide-modified Cu lowered the energy barrier for CO2 protonation and C–C coupling, increase the coverage of hydrogen protons, and promote the C = C bond destruction of the *HCCOH to drive the ethanol generation. Finally, FEEtOH realized 30.1% at −0.62 V [71]. 3.2 Cu-based bimetallic catalysts 3.2.1 CO2-to-methanol The overpotential of Pd for CO2RR is lower but with CO or HCOOH as the main product [74]. However, A Pd-Cu bimetallic aerogel catalyst showed good selectivity of CH3OH. The j and FEMeOH on the Pd83Cu17 aerogel were up to 31.8 mA cm−2 and 80.0%, respectively. The excellent performance of this electrocatalyst was derived from the efficient adsorption and stabilization of CO2 − by aerogel nanochains, high Pd0/Pd2+ and (Cu++Cu0)/Cu2+ ratios, and abundant Pd/Cu grain boundaries [53]. Although Pd-Cu catalysts showed good methanol production properties, metal Pd has the disadvantage of high cost, which is not sufficient for mass production and industrial applications. Therefore, there is an urgent need to find more economical metals. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have shown that the *COOH and *CHO intermediates are more likely to adsorb at the edge of the Se atom than the *CO intermediate [75]. Therefore, as an economical catalyst, Cu-Se NPs exhibited excellent performance for CO2-to-methanol, which showed a low overpotential (0.285 V), high j (41.5 mA cm−2) and FE (77.6%) [51]. Se in catalysts was essential for efficient methanol production, and marginal unsaturated Se could increase exposed active site number, electrical conductivity and CO2RR activity. Therefore, Cu-Se catalyst provided better electrochemical performance with the advantages of low cost, high oxidation state, and electrical conductivity [51,75,76]. 3.2.2 CO2-to-ethanol It has been shown that bimetallic catalysts consisting of Cu and another metal (e.g. Ag and Au) that can selectively catalyze CO2 to CO can increase the content of *CO intermediates, thereby improving the selectivity of C2+ oxygen compounds [62]. Au is a d-zone metal with poor adsorption capacity for hydrogen and oxygen, and is the most typical metal alloyed with Cu in CO2RR [1]. According to Christophe's study [50], the increase in Au concentration promoted CO production and limited the pathway to CH4. This was because the Au in the alloy lowered the activation energy for CO desorption, thus facilitating its desorption at the Cu sites. In the ideal Cu63.9Au36.1 material [13], the FEalcohols was 28% (FEMeOH = 15.9%, FEEtOH = 12%), which was 19 times that of pure Cu. This study indicated that *CO, a key intermediate in the conversion of CO2-to-alcohols, can be optimized for binding in the Cu-Au system, which also suggested that the size and nanostructure of Cu-Au affect the conversion efficiency of alcohols. In another study, two significant factors related to the binding of intermediates, electronic and geometric effects, were found to determine how the intermediates interacted with the surface of a particular catalyst, thus tuning the activity of Cu-Au bimetallic nanoparticles [18]. Cu-Ag alloys have shown advantages in generating alcohols with high FE. Li et al. prepared Cu-Ag alloys in various ratios by co-sputtering [62]. For the Ag0.14/Cu0.86 catalyst, FEEtOH reached 41% at −0.67 V, which was higher than that of the pure Cu (29%). According to DFT calculations, the addition of Ag disrupted the homogeneous Cu sites, leading to a broader CO adsorption peak in the in situ Raman spectroscopy and destabilizing the ethylene intermediate, which in turn facilitated the production of ethanol. Moreover, a Cu3Ag1 electrocatalyst was prepared by electro replacement of an electrodeposited copper substrate (Fig. 3 a). It showed that the presence of Ag in the catalyst promoted the electrons transfer from Cu to Ag atoms (Fig. 3b), resulting in the lack of electrons in Cu, which enhanced the stability of alcohol pathway intermediates like *OCH2CH3 and *OCH2CH3 (Fig. 3f, g) with more negative adsorption free energy. And the final energy level of the ethanol pathway is 0.14 eV lower than that of the ethylene pathway (Fig. 3e), indicating that the ethanol product is thermodynamically more favorable. Eventually, Cu3Ag1 catalyst achieved 63% of FEalcohols at −0.95 V (Fig. 3c, d) [61]. Compared with Cu-Au and Cu-Ag bimetals, non-precious bimetals have more potential for application. Peng et al. prepared a CN vacancy Cu-Co bimetallic catalyst—Cu-Co PBA-VCN (Prussian blue analog with CN vacancies), which possessed low onset potential (−0.21 V), high alcohol production efficiency (FEMeOH = 39.2%, FEEtOH = 44.6%), and good stability (100 h) [77]. Characterization and theoretical calculations show that the spatial site resistance of VCN enhances the generation of CO from *COOH, and the spillover of CO on uniformly dispersed Cu atoms enhances C–C coupling and promotes ethanol production. It was shown that Pd-Cu and Cu-Se bimetallic materials have the advantage of electrocatalytic CO2RR for methanol production, Cu-Au and Cu-Ag have the potential for ethanol production, while Cu-Co bimetallic materials have excellent alcohol (methanol, ethanol) production capability. 3.3 Single-atom Cu-based catalysts 3.3.1 CO2-to-methanol Catalysts consisting only of atomically separated active sites are defined as single-atom catalysts (SACs), which are characterized by high atom utilization efficiency, uniform distribution of tunable active sites, stabilization of intermediates (e.g. *CO2 −), and restriction of adsorbate conformation, thereby increasing catalytic activity and selectivity. Therefore, SACs have attracted great attention since they were proposed in 2011 and have been shown to have higher activity than their cluster or nanoparticle counterparts [22,78]. Yang et al. prepared a material (CuSAs/TCNFs) with a lot of isolated Cu atoms through the synergistic effect of porous carbon fibers to maximize the exposure of Cu active sites and to facilitate CO2 adsorption [56]. Thanks to the large number of penetrating nano-pores distributed in the carbon nano-fibers, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA = 23.3 mF cm−2), CO2 adsorption capacity of CuSAs/TCNFs were 3, 20 times higher than those of CuSAs/CNFs, respectively. In addition, CuSAs/TCNFs have good mechanical properties and can be directly used as working electrodes, which avoids the introduction of polymer binders by the typical coating process, resulting in the decrease of catalyst active sites. The specific structure of CuSAs/TCNFs produces a large number of efficient Cu mono-atoms involved in CO2RR, exhibiting superior FEMeOH and j MeOH with long-term stability. 3.3.2 CO2-to-ethanol Xu et al. reported the preparation of commercial carbon-loaded Cu SAC by Cu-Li incorporation (Fig. 4 a), exhibiting high FEEtOH and low overpotential (−0.4 V) and maintaining FEEtOH at around 90% for 16 h [22]. The FEEtOH was promoted by the high initial dispersion of single Cu atoms. Extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) analyses indicate a dynamic reversible transition of atomically dispersed Cu2+ to the metal Cu3 or Cu4 active sites under reaction conditions with a simultaneous CO2 to ethanol transition. Before CO2RR, Cu2+ was immobilized by four O atoms. At the reduction potential, electrons are transferred from the carbon carrier, reducing Cu2+ to Cu0. Coordination of the first Cu shell layer is transformed from CuO mainly to Cu–Cu, which subsequently combines with nearby Cu atoms to form Cu3 or Cu4 with a stable equilateral triangle or tetrahedral geometry. Without electric field, the Cu molecule was extremely unstable and easily reduced to Cu SAC ions by weak oxidizing agents such as soluble CO2 to Cu SA ions to complete the catalytic cycle (Fig. 4b). Cu molecules attach through hydroxyl groups on the surface and become transiently active sites for binding CO2. A similar Cu SAC to cluster transition is observed on N-modified carbon surfaces [66]. During the catalytic process, metal atoms gradually aggregate into clusters and nanoparticles, resulting in the reduction or even failure of active sites [79]. Xu et al. successfully prepared a carbon-based copper catalyst [80]. In the CO2RR reaction, the FFEtOH is extremely sensitive to the catalyst structure, and once the monoatomic Cu is transformed into CuO and Cu clusters, the activity of CO2RR decreases dramatically. To strengthen the stability of single-atom catalysts, existing methods involve spatial confinement to inhibit metal-atom migration, adjustment of sites to strengthen metal-atom bonding, and inhibition of migration with the help of metal-carrier interaction. At the same time, anchoring atoms at high temperatures and adjusting electronic properties by electron-metal carrier interactions have significantly enhanced catalyst activity and stability [80]. Fontecave et al. developed Cu–N-doped carbon materials (Cu–N-C) with good stability [81]. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) showed that the CuN4 active sites transiently transmigrate during electrochemical processes and recombine to form copper nanoparticles, but this process is reversible and eventually reverts to the CuN4 structure. Ethanol was used as the only liquid-phase product with a FFEtOH of 55% [82]. 3.3.3 CO2-to-propanol It has been demonstrated that direct electrocatalytic CO reduction reaction (CORR) can significantly promote the generation of n-propanol [83], and that CORR has long obtained more than 20% n-propanol FE (FEPrOH) in the flow-cell [84]. Motivated by this background, Wu et al. designed a system consisting of two series electrolyzers using a 3D single-atom nickel (3D Ni-SAG) respectively and multi-hollow Cu2O catalysts for CO2-to-CO and CO-to-n-propanol, respectively [72]. A final FEPrOH of 15.9% was achieved. Cu-based single-atom catalysts have more active exposed sites and higher metal atom utilization and show some potential for alcohol production. The preparation of single-atom Cu catalysts by loading on different porous carbon and nitrogen substrates has different product selectivity. Based on the study of Cu-based single-atom catalysts, the future development of Cu-based dual-atom catalysts (DACs) may help to improve the activity and selectivity of electrocatalytic CO2-to-alcohols. 3.4 Composites of Cu and carbon materials Carbonaceous materials have good mechanical stability, high electrical conductivity, low cost, as well as chemical inertness with negative potential in aqueous solution. It also has a higher HER onset potential than that of metallic materials, which can inhibit the precipitation of H2 in electrolyzed water and thus increase the CO2RR activity, making it a promising material for electrocatalytic CO2RR [85–87]. Porous carbon, with its large specific surface area and adjustable porous structure, provides more active sites and provides the basic prerequisites for CO2 adsorption, mass and electron transfer. In the past decade or so, various carbon-based materials, including carbon nanotubes (CNT), porous carbon, graphite and graphene, have been used as effective electrocatalysts for CO2RR [88–91]. Tuning the hybridization state or nanostructure of carbon atoms by doping heteroatoms and constructing metal components can change their selectivity and activity for CO2RR [89]. Recently, many composite catalysts of Cu and carbon have been explored for the conversion of CO2-to-alcohols. 3.4.1 CO2-to-methanol Based on the multi-electron uptake approach proposed by Klopman [92], modern hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory states that softer acidic sites (i.e., delocalized sites) weaken hard binding capabilities such as *O, *OR (R = H or alkyl) and H2O [57,93,94]. Inspired by HSAB theory, Kong et al. hypothesized that the introduction of suitable off-domain electronic states in isolated ionic Cu could greatly improve their soft acidic properties by decreasing the Cu–O bond strength, thus promoting the Cu–O bond cleavage and *OCH3 (and then CH3OH) formation (Fig. 5 a). Therefore, they prepared a copper cyanamide (Cu2NCN) crystal with a saw-tooth molecular structure to electrocatalytic the conversion of CO2-to-CH3OH. It showed that the cationic polarization induced by the strongly coordinating anion NCN2− altered the pristine electronic structure of isolated Cu+ and greatly increased the dispersion of the electron cloud around each Cu+ (i.e., softer metal sites) (Fig. 5b). Isolated soft Cu+ sites suppressed C–C coupling and induced the breaking of the Cu–O bond in Cu–*O–CH3, which would promote the electroreduction of CO2-to-CH3OH. Cu2NCN exhibited the highest CH3OH selectivity (FE ≈ 70%) with a methanol bias j of −92.3 mA cm−2 [57]. 3.4.2 CO2-to-ethanol Zhao et al. [63] prepared oxide-derived Cu/carbon (OD Cu/C) materials by a facile carbonization of Cu-based MOF (HKUST-1) precursors. The content and type of Cu, specific surface area and porous structure of OD Cu/C could be adjusted by changing the carbonization temperature. OD Cu/C with high Cu+ content obtained at 1000 °C exhibited the best CO2RR activity, converting CO2 to CH3OH/C2H5OH with a total FE of 45.2% ∼ 71.2%. It showed that the synergistic effect of porous carbon and uniformly distributed Cu increased the yield of C2H5OH (13.4 mg L−1 h−1, −0.7 V). The presence of Cu+ induced valence-band electron adsorption of CO2/CO, which facilitated a stronger adsorption of O to the Cu+, leading to the ethanol production at low overpotential (190 mV). This demonstrated that functionalization and conformation of carbon materials are also effective strategies to modulate CO2RR activity and selectivity, apart from adjusting the Cu content and species. As mentioned in 2.2.3, ethylene, which is produced by breaking the C–O bond of the common *CHCOH intermediate of ethylene and ethanol, is the main competing product for the conversion of CO2-to-ethanol [95,96]. Preparation of N-C/Cu [65] by sputter depositing N–C layers on the sputtered Cu NPs surface (Fig. 6 a) had a better production ethanol performance with a FEEtOH of 52 ± 1% at −0.68 V. DFT showed that N–C/Cu has a lower *CO dimerization enthalpy change and potential barrier (Fig. 6b) compared to Cu or C/Cu due to the high electron-donating capacity of the N–C, which facilitated the electron transfer to *CO (Fig. 6c, d) and thus promoted C–C coupling. Moreover, the selective generation of ethanol was improved by inhibiting the deoxygenation process due to the limiting effect of C–O bond breakage in *CHCOH (Fig. 6e, f). Cu combined with carbon-based materials could enhance the FE of C2+ alcohols. Chen et al. [47] used N-doped graphene quantum dots (NGQ) to modify CuO-derived nanorods (Cu-nr). DFT showed that NGQ and Cu-nr acted synergistically in stabilizing the intermediate *C2H3O, thus improving the selectivity of selectivity of the C2+ alcohols (FE = 52.4%, j = 282 mA cm−2, −0.9 V). In conclusion, the introduction of carbon materials into Cu catalysts could improve the dispersion of active sites, stabilize the reaction intermediates, alter the metal-electron distribution, and promotes the electron transfer, thus improving the activity and selectivity of CO2-to-alcohols. The above studies proved that the performance of CO2 conversion to alcohols (FE > 50%) can be largely increased by combining Cu with carbon and nitrogen materials to prepare composites (OD Cu/C, N-C/Cu, Cu-nr, etc.). All previous studies have proved the potential of Cu-based materials in electrocatalyzing CO2 to alcohols. And by preparing Cu-based oxides, bimetallic and monoatomic catalysts and composites, the CO2RR activity and alcohol production can be promoted to a certain extent. However, the problems of low activity, low selectivity, and drastic competitive reactions still exist, with FE of alcohols usually less than 55%). And due to the difficulty of C2+ product generation, there are few studies to realize propanol generation. Therefore, this research of electrocatalytic CO2-to-alcohols still needs to explore more favorable optimization methods. 4 Optimization methods of Cu-based catalysts 4.1 Morphological regulation It has been proved that the electrocatalysts with high surface roughness can rapidly consume CO2 and protons dissolved between catalyst and electrolyte due to its larger contact area, thus increasing the current density in the CO2RR process [97]. And the preparation method affects the roughness and defects on the catalyst surface. Shen et al. [98] prepared two iodide-derived copper electrocatalysts (E-ID-Cu and W-ID-Cu) with different roughness. The selectivity of E-ID-Cu and W-ID-Cu for the C2+ product was much higher than that of Cu foil (EP-Cu), reaching 64.39%, 71.16% for FEC2+ and 251.8, 290.0 mA cm−2 for j C2+, respectively (−1.1 V). Both electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and XRD detection indicated that the defect density increased on E-ID-Cu and W-ID-Cu, and E-ID-Cu was significantly higher than W-ID-Cu (Fig. 7 a–c). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) showed that two ID-Cu catalysts were much rougher compared to EP-Cu, and the roughness of W-ID-Cu was higher than that of E-ID-Cu (Fig. 7d–f). It was indicated that high surface roughness and defect density could increase the d-band of the active site to facilitate the adsorption and dimerization of *CO, thus promoting the generation of C2+ products. Meanwhile, high surface roughness could also prolong the residence time of *C–H and reduce the generation energy of *OCCO and *CH3CH2O, resulting in favorable C2+ generation on W-ID-Cu (Fig. 7g–i). 4.2 Crystalline surface regulation The order of energy barriers of crystalline planes in Cu2O is (110) > (100) > (111) [99]. Kas et al. [100] reported that (110)-oriented Cu2O films slightly decreased in FECO. Cu/Cu2O nanoelectrodes with (100), (110), (111), (200), (211) or (220) crystal planes were found to produce a variety of liquids (e.g. alcohols, acids, aldehydes, etc), but with low FE (1%−30%) [52]. Modulation of electrocatalyst nanostructures by varying catalyst precursors, preparation methods and conditions to expose highly active crystalline surfaces, enlarge surface area, optimize electronic structure and facilitate electron and mass transfer to improve overall catalytic activity [101]. Luo et al. [102] tuned the bare crystalline surface by changing the structure of the pre-catalysts. Three types of Cu-based pre-catalysts with nanowires (NW), nanoparticles (NP), and nanosheets (NS) morphologies were prepared and later subjected to pre-reduction. Among them, Cu NS showed the best selectivity for the production of ethanol, mainly attributed to its rich Cu(100) facets, which facilitated the adsorption and surface coverage of CO, further promoting the dimerization of CO and thus improving the catalytic activity for C2+ products, especially ethanol. Furthermore, A Cu(OH)2-D/Cu foil with abundant (110) and (100) crystal facets, which was shown by in situ ATR-SEIRAS, Raman spectroscopy and DFT calculations that Cu(110) facilitated CO adsorption and Cu(100) promoted C–C coupling into C2+ products. FEC2+ reached 87% and in a Flow-cell at low overpotential (−0.54 V) and high j (217 mA cm−2) [103]. It is noteworthy that Periasamy et al. [21] prepared cuprous oxide/polypyrrole particles (Cu2O(OL-MH)/Ppy) with exposed low-index (111) facets and high-index (211), (311) facets that selectively reduced CO2 to methanol (FEMeOH = 93 ± 1.2%) without any C2 or C3 alcohols. Pyrrole nitrogen was the main active site for CO2, which effectively adsorbed CO2 from the solution and increased the localized CO2 concentration on the surface of the electrode. Moreover, in H3CO− adsorbents, the main (111) surface tends to attach hydrogen to oxygen atoms rather than carbon atoms, which leads to high selectivity for methanol. Due to the improved contact of the electrode/electrolyte with the (311) surface in Cu2O(OL-MH)/Ppy, diffusion and mass transfer energy barriers were reduced, promoting the conversion of CO2-to-methanol (Fig. 8 ). Kroger-Vink also explained the involvement of oxygen vacancies in the CO2RR process with larger kinks and steps on the high-index (311) surface than on the low-index (111) surface, which provides better interface contact and high surface energy [104]. However, there are some reports that found preferential formation of CH4 on the Cu(111) [105]. The effect and mechanism of the crystallographic face on product selectivity is yet to be further investigated. 4.3 Oxidation state regulation The oxidation state is defined as “the degree of oxidation of an atom in terms of counting electrons” [106]. The oxidation state of a catalyst has a great influence on its CO2RR performance. First, reactant activation can be promoted by modulating the oxidation state of the catalyst, and it was found that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Cu+ could facilitate CO2 activation [107]. Second, a computational study [108] revealed that the adsorption of *CO could be monotonically increased with the increase of Cu oxidation state. In addition, DFT calculations found that the Gibbs free energy for *OCCOH intermediates formation in electrodeposited Cu catalysts (25% Cu-content) was lower than that of pure Cu, suggesting that Cu facilitates the dimerization reaction [109]. The oxidation state affects the structure, physicochemical properties of the catalyst by changing the spin state, work function, active sites and energy bands, thus modulating the catalyst activity and selectivity (Fig. 9 ). (1) The oxidation state regulates the reaction by changing the spin state. Xu et al. adjusted the spin state of Co3 + in LaCoO3 to a high spin state more conducive to adsorption of H2O molecules by Fe substitution, which promoted the oxygen evolution reaction [110]. (2) The work function is positively correlated with the oxidation state and can be used to judge the electron transfer ability. A low value of work function for an electrocatalyst, means that electrons can be easily transferred from electrode to reactant for the reaction. (3) The electron distribution and d electron density of the catalyst can be also changed by adjusting the oxidation state. A larger overlap of electronic states promotes CO2 adsorption and activation, thus improving the reactivity of the active site. (4) In addition, oxidation state tuning also affects the relative positions between the conduction band, valence band, and Fermi level. Strong bonds are formed when the d-band of the site moves upward, and weak bonds are formed when the d-band moves downward [111]. It has been demonstrated that the pre-oxidation of Cu can greatly improve its ability to produce C2+ products [16]. 4.4 Elemental doping Although Cu-based materials are the most promising catalysts reported for the production of methanol [112], their lack of stability under reducing conditions has led to a continuous decrease in alcohols yield. Elemental doping can produce catalytic high-energy surfaces and enhance the methanol production efficiency [111,113]. In addition, lattice strain and ligand effects induced by elemental doping can modulate the surface electronic structure and its interactions with intermediates, thus enhancing catalyst activity [114,115]. Common types of dopants include anionic and cationic dopants [101]. Anionic doping mainly includes N and S elemental doping, and cationic doping is mainly metal cation doping. Anionic doping is commonly used in electrocatalytic CO2RR alcohol production, so the main focus here is on the doping of non-metallic elements. CO2 is known to be a weak Lewis acid, but the neutral C in carbon materials is chemically inert. Due to the high electronegativity of N, the doping of N can form negatively charged N and positively charged C, which can effectively improve the CO2 adsorption capacity of carbon materials [116]. Song et al. developed a copper nanoparticle loaded N-doped carbon nanospike (Cu/CNS) electrode that inhibited HER and showed high CO2RR efficiency with the FEEtOH of 63% (−1.2 V) [64]. The N-doped carbon nanospikes were bent and curved, providing sufficient reaction sites for the adsorption of *OCCO intermediates to promote C2H5OH generation. An efficient CO2 electroreduction catalyst with CuO clusters supported on N-doped carbon nanosheets (Cu/N0.14C) was investigated by Su et al. [59]. The catalysts had a high FEC2+ (∼73%) with an FEEtOH of 51% at −1.1 V. Operando XAS and XPS showed a potentially dependent structural transition of the CuO cluster to the CuN3 fraction, which was reversible (Fig. 10 a). The FE got maximum when the Cu2-CuN3 cluster was formed at −1.1 V, indicating that the Cu2-CuN3 cluster is the optimum site. Operando FTIR and theoretical calculations showed that *CH3 is the main intermediate and the adsorption of *CH3 strengthens the charge asymmetric Cu2-CuN3 cluster. It is interesting to note that the Cu atoms s showed an asymmetric distribution of charges, with the main charge transfer occurring at the Cu-N3 site (Fig. 10b, c). The charge asymmetry sites are the cause of the generation of asymmetric ethanol, in which N doping is instrumental in the uniform dispersion of the reduced Cu clusters, as well as the electron transfer and charge distribution between the metal atoms and the substrate. In addition to the common anionic doping, it has been shown that metal doping in Cu-based catalysts can be effective in improving the selectivity of specific products, e.g., by doping small amounts of the metals Au [13] or Ag [62]. This is summarized in the bimetallic section, and therefore will not be repeated here. The double doping of anions and cations with opposite charge states brings more space for the regulation of catalyst activity. Li et al. studied the effect of double doping in Cu2O/Cu matrix on the CO2-to-CH3OH process using cations (Ag, Au, Zn, and Cd) and anions (S, Se, and I) [54]. It showed that Ag and S double doping has good performance with the FEMeOH of 67.4% and the j of 122.7 mA cm−2 at −1.18 V in an ionic liquid/H2O electrolyte. DFT calculations showed that S changed the electronic structure of adjacent Cu atoms and lowered the forming energy barrier of *CHO, a key intermediate for formic acid formation. While Ag mainly increased the reaction barrier of HER. Their synergistic effect with Cu2O/Cu improved the FE and j of methanol generation. So far, the mechanism of influence between the different components in the catalyst (carrier, active site and doping element) is not clear, and the efficiency of alcohol generation is still low [51,53,117]. Therefore, the main bottleneck of element doping is how to regulate the effects between different components to modulate the activity and selectivity of catalysis [54]. 4.5 Defect engineering Defects are sites where the internal structural integrity is compromised. The defect introduction in catalysts can modulate the electronic structure, providing a lot of unsaturated sites, thus improving the activity and selectivity of the electrocatalyst. Common types of defects are intrinsic defects, anionic vacancies, cationic vacancies, lattice distortions and heteroatom doping [118]. 4.5.1 Metallic vacancy Ren et al. reported that Cu nanocrystals of size ∼15 nm with high number of defect surfaces exhibited better n-propanol generation activity [48]. The onset potential of n-propanol formation was 200–300 mV higher than that of electrolytically polished Cu surfaces or Cu0 nanoparticles. And the j of Cu nanocrystals (j n-propanol = −1.74 mA cm−2) was approximately 25 times than that of Cu0 nanoparticles at −0.95 V. The enhancement of n-propanol formation may be associated with the surface distribution of defect sites on Cu nanocrystals. Sargent et al. [119] developed a core–shell Cu2S-CuV (where V denotes vacancies) material by solvothermal method. DFT calculations showed that the copper vacancies lowered the overpotential and overcame the C–C coupling energy barriers, with 15% ± 1% for FEEtOH and 8% ± 0.7% for FEPrOH at −0.95 V. 4.5.2 Non-metallic vacancy Ionic vacancies have been shown to be a class of active sites that can enhance CO2 adsorption and activation to form C1, C2, and C2 + products [119–121]. Conventional methods of vacancy formation, such as high temperature annealing [120] and wet chemical reduction [122], tend to form dispersed vacancies with limited hierarchy. Oxygen vacancies have special interactions with O atoms, favoring CO2RR to alcohols. Daiyan et al. [123] reported a 3D Cu sandwich electrode enriched with Cu+/Cu2 + interfaces and oxygen vacancies with 31% FEEtOH. Copper sulfide (CuS) mainly generates HCOOH [124] or CH4 [125] during electrocatalytic CO2RR. As two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dihalides, hexagonal CuS has an abundance of surface sulfur atoms in the lamellar (001) and (100) directions with relatively low dissociation energy of Cu–S bonds [126]. So S can be removed to form sulfur vacancies (labeled CuS x (0 < x < 1), which can reduce the oxidation of copper to between 0 ∼ +2 and thus promote C–C coupling [126–128]. The dynamic formation of Cu δ+ (0 < δ < 1) species during CO2RR has been reported as the catalytic center of ethanol formation due to their moderate electron-donor capacity to neutralize positively charged C atoms [129–131]. During the CO2RR on Cu2S, S are gradually removed and dissolved in the electrolyte, resulting in the establishment of Cu2S1 − x with an abundant anion vacancy [132]. And Guo et al. [68] synthesized Cu2S1 − x HN with rich sulfur vacancy by electroreduction of CuS hollow nanocubs (CuS HN), which showed a FEEtOH of 73.3 % at −0.3 V. Besides, Sargent et al. [119] found that the surface vacancy modification of Cu2S cores resulted in an FE value of 8% ± 0.7% for n-propanol. DFT calculations showed that double sulfur vacancy (DSV) formed on the hexagonal CuS can act as an effective electrocatalytic center to stabilize *CO and *OCCO, and further C–C coupling to form CO-OCCO (Fig. 11 c), which is not possible on Cu with no or single sulfur vacancies. Peng et al. [23] developed a DSV structure (Fig. 11d, e) via electrochemical lithium using a lithium electrochemical tuning method (Fig. 11a, b). The more cycles of charging and discharging, the more S atoms were removed, so the sulfur vacancies density can be controlled by the count of cycles. Finally, the FEPrOH of CuS x -DSV reached 15.4% ± 1% at −1.05 V. All in all, it has been shown that the conversion of CO2 to alcohols can be significantly enhanced by morphology, crystal surface, oxidation state modulation, defect engineering and elemental doping of Cu-based catalysts, and the FEalcohols could generally reach 65%∼90%, and even 93%±1.2% of FEEtOH was achieved on Cu2O(OL-MH)/Ppy. In spite of the above, the catalyst preparation methods are mostly more complicated, which implies a higher preparation cost. In addition, the intrinsic reaction mechanism and promotion mechanism of CO2 alcohol production have not been fully revealed, which is a crucial step to realize the targeted alcohol production. In this process, the introduction of theoretical calculations and machine learning has been proved to be efficient, convenient and indispensable, which will promote the theoretical depth of CO2RR. 5 Mechanisms of alcohol production by electrocatalytic CO2RR 5.1 Advanced technology use in electrocatalytic CO2RR technology 5.1.1 In-situ spectroscopic techniques X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) including X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), is obtained by synchrotron radiation to probe the structural or chemical information of catalysts. XANES is mainly used to detect the valence states of absorbing atoms. EXAFS signal oscillates, which originate from the sprayed photoelectron interactions of adsorbed atoms with the neighboring atoms, is a powerful tool to quantify the coordination numbers, bond lengths and order factors that are directly relevant to CO2RR activity and selectivity (Fig. 12 a). Hence, XAS can be utilized to probe the properties of the active site in depth and to study the constitutive relationship of catalyst and CO2RR selectivity [133]. Despite the tremendous development of electrocatalytic CO2RR technology, the intrinsic reaction mechanism of CO2RR has not yet been finalized, and the mechanism of the influence of the microscopic parameters at the interface between the catalyst and the electrolyte on CO2RR is yet to be further revealed. By introducing in situ spectroscopic techniques (e.g. surface-enhanced infrared adsorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS) or surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), etc.), surface-adsorbed intermediates can be identified and observed in relation to parameters such as potential, electrode surface and electrolyte composition [9]. The SEIRAS cell is separated into two parts by an ion-exchange membrane (Fig. 12b). The working electrode is formed by depositing a thin metal catalyst on a Si (or Ge) crystal. An infrared beam is reflected inside the Si-metal interface, generating a solution-penetrating transient wave (Fig. 12c) that detects substances (1–10 nm) in the vicinity of the electrodes, thus identifying surface substances and reaction intermediates produced during the CO2RR process [133]. SERS can track the generation and conversion of surface substances with high sensitivity through plasma resonance effects on localized surfaces [134]. The two compartments of the electrochemical Raman cell are also separated by an ion-exchange membrane (Fig. 12d). The adsorption of CO, an important intermediate in the CO2RR process, can be assessed from the material electronic structure or the catalyst-electrolyte interaction (Fig. 12e). SERS has the advantage of recognizing the low-frequency bonding from 50 to 1000 cm−1, such as Cu–C vibration (365 cm−1) [135]. However, this test is limited by the low concentration of CO at the surface of the material, and to solve this problem, Flow-cells can be used to increase the reaction rate and the accumulation at the surface [136]. In addition, localized electrode pH can be determined by Raman spectroscopy to understand how the surface pH distribution affects CO2RR activity and selectivity (Fig. 12f) [133]. 5.1.2 Theoretical computation and machine learning It is significant for the rational design of catalysts to explore the reaction mechanism and active site of catalysts through theoretical calculation [137]. Zhao et al. [138] have comparatively calculated the activity, pathways and selectivity for CO2-to-C1 process such as methanol on the single-atom catalyst (SAC) M−N4 model and the dual-atom catalyst (DAC) MCu-N6 (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) model by density-functional theory (DFT). CO2RR is enhanced by promoting electron transfer effects through orbital hybridization between the key intermediate *COOH 2p orbital near the Fermi energy level and the adjacent metal 3d orbital. From Fe to Zn, this effect gradually diminishes to for MCu-N6 as the electronegativity difference between Cu and M decreases. This work reveals the mechanism for CO2RR of Cu in DAC. Although much progress has been made, traditional theoretical calculations are very time-consuming for large systems [139]. The rapid development of machine learning (ML) for the simulation of CO2RR can be greatly extended in time and spatial scales [137,140,141]. To investigate the synergy between Cu and Zn in ZnO/Cu2O nanocubes, the evolution of bimetallic structural and the effect of Zn on the kinetics of Cu redox behavior. Martina et al. [142] used a combination of operational fast X-ray absorption fine structure (QXAFS) spectroscopy, ML, and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) techniques to investigate the changes in material chemistry and structure over time during CO2RR at −500 mA cm−2. In conclusion, the introduction and application of advanced technologies such as ML, high-throughput computing and materials genome engineering (MGE) in the materials field are promising approaches to develop high-performance materials compared to the traditional trial-and-error method [143]. 5.2 The key factors of electrocatalytic conversion of CO2-to-alcohols 5.2.1 CO2 adsorption and activation CO2 is a stable nonpolar linear molecule with C = O bond energy of 799 kJ mol−1. CO2 adsorption and activation is considered to be the first step of CO2RR, during which chemical bonds are formed between CO2 and the active sites, resulting in a bending of the linear structure of CO2 and a weakening of the C = C bonds [144]. CO2 gains an electron from atomic interactions at the catalyst surface, forming a partially charged carboxylate (CO2 −), a typical activation intermediate with three adsorption forms (Fig. 13 ) [28,146]. Another theory of adsorption comes from DFT simulations, which assumes that CO and formate have different precursors-carboxyl (*COOH) and formyloxy (*OCHO), respectively [147]. Regarding how these two species are formed, Nørskov et al. [148] suggested that they are formed via proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET), while Goddard et al. [149] proposed the CO2 − protonation pathway (Fig. 13). And the third type of adsorption may be the one-step conversion of CO2 into bicarbonate (HCO3 −) by addition of OH− (Fig. 13) [145,150]. Furthermore, three typical coordination modes can be classified according to the adsorbed intermediates of CO2 on the catalyst surface: carbon coordination (Fig. 13, yellow), oxygen coordination (Fig. 13, red) and mixed coordination (Fig. 13, blue) [151,152]. And according to the number of binders, they can be categorized into single-dentate binding and double-dentate binding mode [146]. The mode of CO2 adsorption depends on the surface atomic state and nature of the catalyst. And then CO2 − is further reduced by obtaining electrons. The mode of CO2 − adsorption largely dictates the CO2RR pathway. For instance, carbon coordination is favorable for the generation of carboxyl radical (*COOH), whereas oxygen coordination is more favorable for H–C attachment in a bidentate binding structure that facilitates the formation of formate anion [153]. Therefore, better adsorption and activation of CO2 by catalysts can improve CO2 utilization and reduce the reaction potential, while different adsorption intermediates can largely affect the reaction pathway of CO2RR and consequently the product selectivity [151,154]. 5.2.2 Competitive reaction Since the potential of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, 0 V) is more positive than that of CO2RR (∼−1 V), H2 produced by proton reduction usually competes for electrons and is preferentially reduced over CO2. Although it has been demonstrated that various alcohols can be produced at Cu electrodes, Cu is also catalytically active towards HER [155,156], which may become a serious competing reaction in the CO2RR process [24]. In order to realize the conversion of CO2 rather than the generation of H2 from H2O over electrocatalysts, the selectivity for CO2RR must be improved. In addition, because of the wide variety of products possible with Cu-based catalysts, the alcohols are not favored by the more readily produced C1 products such as CO, HCOOH, and CH4, or C2+ products such as C2H4. In CO2RR, methane is the main competitive product for methanol generation, with *OCH3 being the key intermediate that determines its selectivity [27,157]. When the interaction of O atoms with the surface is weak, it favors *OCH3 desorption to form MeOH; while when the interaction is strong, the O–CH3 bond is easily broken to form CH4 [1]. In addition, C2H4 is a major competitor for CH3CH2OH because they share the same key intermediate (*CHCOH), where C2H4 is produced by breaking the C–O bond and CH3CH2OH is produced by breaking the M−C bond between the active site M and *CHCOH [95,96]. 5.2.3 C–C coupling C–C coupling is a key step in C2+ alcohols formation. CO2 first forms adsorbed *CO (Fig. 13), which is a key intermediate in C–C coupling [9]. The widely recognized mechanism for C–C coupling is direct binary coupling, including coupling between *CHO and *CH2 in addition to *CO, especially at high overpotentials [158]. Therefore the formation of a high concentration of intermediates such as *CO/*CHO/*CH2 on the surface of the material with a sufficient overpotential and high catalytic activity is a prerequisite for successful C–C coupling. 5.3 Reaction pathways and key intermediates Electrochemical CO2RR involves multi-electron and multi-proton transfer processes resulting in various products. The paths are different for generating different products, which makes the difficult exploring of CO2RR mechanism. In general, CO2 reduction mechanism is proposed based on possible intermediates derived from DFT theoretical calculations combined with in situ/operational characterization techniques [3]. The identification of these key intermediates is essential for the rational design of catalysts for the selective CO2RR products. The possible reaction pathways and the key intermediates for the reduction of CO2 to different products are presented (Fig. 14 , Involves only the key intermediates that determine the reaction pathway). *CO species is the key intermediate in determining the CO2RR selectivity. Depending on its adsorption strength to the catalyst surface, it may undergo three types of pathways: (a) Desorption to generate CO; (b) hydrogenation to C1 products (e.g. methanol); (c) dimerization to C2 products (e.g. ethanol) [159]. 5.3.1 The pathways of CO2 to CH3OH CO2 is first converted to *CO intermediate by removing an O atom, and when the catalyst surface is sufficiently bonded to *CO, *CO continues to be hydrogenated to produce *OCH or *COH intermediate. Subsequently, *OCH can be further hydrogenated to produce *CH2OH and then *CH3OH, so methanol (CH3OH) will be dissociated. And, *COH intermediate can also be detached from the catalyst surface by progressive hydrogenation to produce CH3OH (Fig. 14). 5.3.2 The pathways of CO2 to C2H5OH The reduction of CO2 to C2H5OH requires C–C coupling (Fig. 15 a), which results in the dimerization of *CO to form *C2O2 −, which is then further protonated to *COCOH or *COCHO [160,161]. Subsequently, *COCOH may be formed as *COCH2OH during hydrogenation and further reduced to C2H5OH or C2H4. And *COCHO is further reduced by hydrogenation and removal of H2O to the *CH2CHO intermediate, which in subsequent hydrogenation steps produces C2H5OH. *CH2CHO is recognized as a crucial intermediate in the CO2-to-C2H5OH process [9]. 5.3.3 The pathways of CO2 to C3H7OH The first C–C bond in the generation of C3H7OH has the same pathway as that of C2H5OH (Fig. 15b). The *C2O2 − species obtained by dimerization of *CO are reduced to either *COCOH or *COCHO intermediates, where *COCOH plays a crucial role in the generation of C2 or C3 products. *COCOH is converted to *CHCH3 by two C–O(H) bond breaks and hydrogenation and then combines with another adsorbed *CO, which is further converted to C3H7OH by a sequence of electron and proton transfers. The second coupling occurs in two ways, by dimerization culminating in the formation of C3H7OH and by insertion culminating in CH3COCH3. The construction of dual active sites for electrocatalysts could improve the C–C coupling and propanol formation through synergistic effects [159]. There are two reasons for the low selectivity of n-propanol. One is the creation of electrocatalytic sites to stabilize key C2 intermediates for the formation of n-propanol [9,160,162]. Another is the complex coupling mechanism between C1 and C2 species, with two different models previously proposed for CO-CH2CHO [17,163,164] and CO-OCCO [162,165,166], with OCCOCO* being the most recommended *C3 intermediate in CO2RR [80]. In addition, the difficulty in C2 and C2+ products formation with acceptable activity lies in the proportionality between the binding and activation energies of the intermediates. This requires that the active site binds key intermediates such as *CO, *CH2, and others tightly enough to establish sufficient coverage for the subsequent of C–C coupling, but avoiding too tight a binding to increase the activation potential. Cu is the most potential materials to fulfill this requirement because Cu+ species have the proper affinity for *CO, which is a key intermediate in C–C coupling [3]. 6 Conclusion and prospects Because the high energy density and market demand of alcohols, electrocatalytic CO2RR to form alcohols is a promising development direction. Among many materials, Cu-based catalysts embody advantages for the generation of alcohols. Despite the potential of Cu-based catalysts to promote alcohol generation, pure copper has low selectivity for alcohol generation, and it was found that copper oxide, Cu-based bimetallic and monoatomic catalysts, and composites formed by Cu and carbon materials are more favorable for alcohol generation. In addition, the activity of Cu-based catalysts and the selectivity of alcohols generation were improved by adjusting the exposed crystal plane, electron cloud structure, and increasing the active sites through morphological regulation, elemental doping, oxidation state regulation and defect engineering in Cu-based materials. Exploring the intrinsic mechanism of the reaction is the basis for achieving catalyst modulation. And by sorting out the reaction pathway, the key intermediates in the pathway are summarized, which is of guiding significance for the design of catalysts. Although several scholars have invested in the study of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to alcohols, and some of them have reached more than 90% FE, the electrocatalytic CO2RR technology still suffers from the technical obstacles of insufficient catalyst activity, limited selectivity, and insufficient stability. The technology seems to be far from adequate when it comes to the practical application of CO2 reduction to make usable low-carbon fuels. Suggestions for better optimization and development of the technology in the future are as follows. (1) Modulation to prepare higher performance electrocatalysts to overcome the bottleneck of low activity and selectivity of alcohol production on Cu-based catalysts. More efficient catalysts are prepared through strategies such as morphology modulation, elemental doping, and defect introduction. In addition, the Cu-based catalysts generate a complex range of products, so improving the selectivity of the target products as well as the later product purification needs further consideration. (2) Utilize product and intermediate analysis techniques (e.g. on-line differential electrochemical-mass spectrometry, in situ infrared spectroscopy and in situ Raman spectroscopy, etc.) with fast and accurate response to solve the problem of difficult characterization of CO2RR mechanism. Other analytical techniques (e.g. in situ X-ray diffraction, X-ray adsorption spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy, etc.) for material characterization are also important to reveal dynamic mechanisms of electrocatalysis. In addition, some smart isotope techniques that reflect Operando information are also critical. (3) Establishing conformational relationships between atomic structures and products to guide the directed preparation and modulation of catalysts. It is difficult to explain the changes in the catalyst structure at different potentials with respect to the products because the relationship between the atomic structure and the products is not well understood. Therefore, establishing the conformational relationships between atomic structures and products is an urgent need for designing electrocatalysts. (4) Introducing machine learning and theoretical computing for efficient catalyst design and prediction. Intelligent theoretical simulation and prediction will undoubtedly greatly reduce the time and labor cost of CO2RR materials selection compared to the traditional laboratory trial-and-error synthesis and testing. Applying machine learning with high-throughput DFT computational training to the field of catalytic materials can quickly achieve rapid screening and matching of materials for performance prediction. Yaru Lei is currently a master's student at the School of energy and environmental engineering at University of Science and Technology Beijing, China. Her research focuses on electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Xiaolong Tang is a professor of energy and environmental engineering at University of Science and Technology Beijing, China. He received his Ph.D. degree from Beijing Institute of Technology in 2006. His research interests include air pollution control technology, industrial waste gas resource utilization, environmental functional materials, etc. Xiubing Huang is a professor of materials science and engineering at University of Science and Technology Beijing, China. He received his Ph.D degree from University of St Andrews in 2015. His research interests include targeted design, controllable synthesis, property modulation of nanocomposites and their applications in the fields of catalytic organic synthesis and phase change energy storage, etc. Fengyu Gao is an associate professor of energy and environmental engineering at University of Science and Technology Beijing, China. He received his Ph.D. degree from University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2017. His research interests include air pollution control and resource utilization, and environmental energy catalysis, etc.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) technology, which enables carbon capture storage and resource utilization by reducing CO2 to valuable chemicals or fuels, has become a global research hotspot in recent decades. Among the many products of CO2RR (carbon monoxide, acids, aldehydes and alcohols, olefins, etc.), alcohols (methanol, ethanol, propanol, etc.) have a higher market value and energy density, but it is also more difficult to produce. Copper is known to be effective in catalyzing CO2 to high value-added alcohols, but with poor selectivity. The progress of Cu-based catalysts for the selective generation of alcohols, including copper oxides, bimetals, single atoms and composites is reviewed. Meanwhile, to improve Cu-based catalyst activity and modulate product selectivity, the modulation strategies are straighten out, including morphological regulation, crystalline surface, oxidation state, as well as elemental doping and defect engineering. Based on the research progress of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction for alcohol production on Cu-based materials, the reaction pathways and the key intermediates of the electrocatalytic CO2RR to methanol, ethanol and propanol are summarized. Finally, the problems of traditional electrocatalytic CO2RR are introduced, and the future applications of machine learning and theoretical calculations are prospected. An in-depth discussion and a comprehensive review of the reaction mechanism, catalyst types and regulation strategies were carried out with a view to promoting the development of electrocatalytic CO2RR to alcohols.
